She is also very good mother, who takes care of her children and carries out  her responsibilities as a housewife. She has given birth to four children, three sons and a daughter. Two of them are attending school and the other two are not yet of age.
Her husband runs a tea stall in the local market and sells a variety of tea such as green, creamy and milk tea to his customers.  He has been doing this business for the last 10 years. 

Azra perveen is applying for a loan for the first time from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) for her husband, who wants to expand his business. With the loan capital, he will buy supplies such as milk, tea and sugar in bulk. 
Note: “Azra is cooking at the stove in this picture”.

loans.use: Purchase items fo a  tea stall

loans.name: Haydee

texts.en:
Haydee R. is a young mother who aims to become successful someday by developing her fishing business. Her husband works as a fisherman. They work together for the future of their family. Since joining ASHI, Haydee has been improving her quality of life. With the additional income from her business, Haydee has funded the education of her children. Haydee believes sending her kids to school will set them up for continued success in their college studies and future careers.

She has used her Kiva loan to purchase fishing materials needed of her business. With the profits from her business venture, Haydee has been encouraged to continued her fishing operation. She has also used her profits to help other relatives from her community and neighborhood. 

She expresses her deepest and sincerest gratitude to ASHI and Kiva lenders for the support of her business venture, the education of her children, and supporting members of her community.

At 34-years-old Haydee is determined to work hard and achieve continued success with her business ventures. Haydee thanks you in advance for funding her loan as it has helped her family greatly.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials needed of her business.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng V. was born in 1973 and is currently living in a village near Phnom Penh, the capital. She earns her daily living by growing various vegetables on her own land in her village. Since 2005, Cheng V. has sold her mature crops to her buyers every two or three months after she plants. Her husband is a domestic construction worker. This couple has three young children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, while one attends school. Cheng V. has requested a loan to repair her motorcycle that often breaks down when she uses it to commute.

loans.use: To repair a motorcycle.

loans.name: Santa

texts.en:
Santa A., 42, is married to a soldier and they have four children, all attending school. Currently in the business of selling beads and necklaces at the market. she is requesting a loan to stock packets of beads to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Santa hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock packets of beads to sell

loans.name: Aisalkyn's Group

texts.ru:
Порою, начиная какое – либо дело, мы сами далеко не осознаём, к чему оно нас приведёт. Но по прошествии уже определённого промежутка времени, мы начинаем получать конкретные результаты за проделанный труд и приложенные усилия. Мы также начинаем получать и материальное, и моральное удовлетворение за все старания и лишения и только тогда, мы начинаем понимать, всю значимость проделанной работы. Поэтому сильные люди никогда не сдаются, а наоборот упорно ждут плодов своих начинаний, зная, что временные трудности на то и временные, чтобы их переждать. Айсалкын Шерматова – лидер данной группы. Она из г. Балыкчи. Айсалкын начала торговать десять лет назад на старом рынке, накопив сбережения в размере десяти тысяч сомов. Сейчас она – опытный предприниматель и те самые деньги, что она вложила, чтобы начать свой бизнес, Айсалкын теперь зарабатывает за месяц. И её бизнес – это неотъемлемая часть семейного дохода. Муж Айсалкын работает водителем. Он возит клиентов за товаром. У Айсалкын двое детей. Сыну двадцать лет. Он учится в физкультурном институте. А дочке десять лет. Она учится в начальной школе. Благодаря своему бизнесу Айсалкын удаётся оплачивать контракт за обучения сына, а это семнадцать тысяч сомов в год. Недавно они также отремонтировали свой дом и купили машину. Айсалкын понимает, какое важное решение она приняла десять лет назад, когда отправилась торговать на рынок. Сейчас Айсалкын нуждается в кредите. Ей нужны средства для того, чтобы купить летний ассортимент детских вещей. 
Партнёры Айсалкын по группе:

Бозовой Алтынай 43 года. У неё двое детей. Алтынай с мужем – предприниматели. Он торгует обувью в г. Бишкек, а она продаёт женское бельё. Она обратилась за этим кредитом, чтобы помочь мужу в увеличении ассортимента товаров, а именно, купить летние сланцы. 

Койчумановой Бурулсун 34 года. Она разведена и одна воспитывает семилетнюю дочь, которая этой осенью пойдёт в школу. Бурулсун продаёт детские вещи. Этим она уже занимается пять лет и сейчас её доход составляет двенадцать тысяч сомов. Бурулсун нужен этот кредит, чтобы купить вещи летнего сезона. 

Чуменову Кайраткелди 37 лет. Он – отец двоих детей. Сей час вместе с супругой Кайраткелди торгует детскими вещами. Его доход составляет двенадцать тысяч сомов. Кайраткелди обратился за этим кредитом, так как хочет увеличить ассортимент товаров и сделать закупку новых видов детских вещей. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
At times, when starting any kind of business, we do not realize what the outcome may be. But after a certain period of time has passed, we begin to obtain concrete results for our labor and efforts. We also begin to have financial and moral satisfaction for all of the efforts and sacrifices, and only then do we begin to understand the meaning of our work. This is why strong people never give up; on the contrary, they stubbornly wait for the fruits of their beginnings, knowing that difficulties are temporary and designed to be endured. Aisalkyn S. is the leader of this group. She is from the city of Balykchi. She started sales ten years ago at an old market, having saved a sum of ten thousand som. Now, she is an experienced entrepreneur and earns that same amount of money that she invested to start her business in one month. Her business is an essential part of the family income. Aisalkyn’s husband works as a driver. He transports clients to get merchandise. Aisalkyn has two children. Her son is twenty years old. He attends a sports and exercise college. Her daughter is ten years old. She goes to elementary school. Thanks to her business, Aisalkyn is able to pay her son’s education contract, which is seventeen thousand som per year. Recently, they also remodeled their house and bought a car. Aisalkyn understands what an important decision it was to start sales at the market ten years ago. Currently, she needs a loan in order to buy summer assortment of children’s goods. Aisalkyn’s group partners are: Altynai B. is 43 years old. She has two children. Altynai and her husband are entrepreneurs. He sells shoes in the city of Bishkek, and she sells women’s undergarments. She requested this loan in order to help her husband expand merchandise assortment and primarily, to buy summer sandals. Burulsun K. is 34 years old. She is divorced and raising a seven-year-old daughter, who will start school in the autumn, alone. Burulsun sells children’s goods. She has been involved in this business for five years, and her current income is twelve thousand som. Burulsun needs this loan in order to buy summer merchandise. Kairatkeldi C. is 37 years old. He is a father of two children. Currently, together with his wife, Kairatkeldi sells children’s goods. His income is twelve thousand som. He requested this loan because he wants to expand merchandise assortment and make a purchase of new kinds of children’s goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer assortment of children's goods

loans.name: Mwanajaa

texts.en:
Mwanajaa, a married mother of four children all attending school, supplies building materials to potential customers from her quarry site, a business she has been operating for four years. Mwanajaa's customers are her neighbors and passersby. She faces the challenge of seasonality and high transport costs and therefore joined Yehu in order to qualify for loans to deal with those challenges. With the Ksh 30,000 loan she is requesting, Mwanajaa intends to pay the laborers and the costs incurred transporting building materials ready for sale.

Mwanajaa lives in a rental house, with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To pay for quarry site, wages for quarry miners and transport to her home.

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is involved in a cloth selling business. She buys cloth from Faisalabad (which is famous for its textile industry) and sells in different markets of her city. She lives in the small city of Vehari, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She has three children: two boys and a girl. One of them is four years old and not yet started going to school; the other two are getting their education. 

Safia wants her children to complete their education and for this she works very hard. She is applying for a loan because she wants more variety in her stock. She will buy high quality fabric which can earn her more money.

loans.use: To purchase cloth in bulk to sell

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola M. is currently in the business of selling necklaces and earrings in a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more earrings to sell. Viola is 39 years old and is married to a clerk. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more earrings to sell

loans.name: Feruzahon's Group

texts.en:
Life obstacles and difficulties make people stronger and wiser. They give us the experience which later helps us improve our lives and make a better living. The heroes of our story also regard the difficulties in life just as good practical lessons for the future and definite steps toward a better life. 

Feruzahon M. is the leader of this group. She is forty-two and has four children. One of her children is disabled. He has a disability of the 3rd degree. Her husband is in Russia at the moment. He has gone there in search of a job. To provide for the family, Feruzahon tends a cow and a calf and is occupied with farming. Her eldest daughter works as a seamstress and thus helps her mother to meet their daily needs.  

Due to cattle breeding, farming, and her husband’s support they have been able to build a new house. Recently they have even managed to repair three rooms. Feruzahon is planning to marry off her daughter and provide her disabled son with a good treatment. But to achieve all this she needs to save sufficient funds. Therefore, Feruzahon has decided to apply for this loan to buy a cow to raise. 

Halidahon M., 46, is a mother of three children. Her eldest son is a baker and her daughter is a seamstress. Halidahon’s husband works as a private builder. Currently Halidahon is engaged in the repair of their house. She needs this loan to finish the repair and prepare for her son’s wedding. 

Odina A., 47, is a farmer. She used to grow wheat in the past, but now she grows potatoes and sunflowers. As for her husband, he is working in Russia. Odina has two children. Now, she needs a loan to purchase mineral fertilizers for potatoes and sunflowers. 

Halimahon I., 48, is divorced. She is looking after her old mother and her two children. To provide for the family, Halimahon is engaged in cattle breeding and also works as a nurse. She hopes to obtain this loan and purchase three sheep for fattening and resale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase a cow for breeding

loans.name: Doch

texts.en: Mrs. Doch K. has been in the farming business for years. She plants rice and some vegetable crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of US$ 1.50 per day. Her husband earns his living as a construction foreman, earning US$ 5.50 a day. This couple has been married for years and has four children. The family doesn’t have the ability to buy a vehicle for their traveling needs since their current revenue is just enough to feed them, so they always hire a taxi for commuting. To help reduce this expense, Doch K. would like to ask for a US$ 500 loan to purchase a second-hand motorbike to provide transportation for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorbike to provide transportation for their family

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes N. is currently in the business of selling text books, exercise books, etc. in a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more books to sell.  Agnes is 42 years old and is single.   With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her bookshop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

 In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more books to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a married woman with one child who goes to school. With the Ksh 20,000, she hopes to buy cloth, sewing thread, and a sewing machine. Her business involves making school uniforms and other clothing for the entire community. Janet has been operating her in-house tailoring business for the past six years. Her other source of income is her spouse's salary.

She faces the challenge of seasonality as demand fluctuates. She hopes to progress in life by expanding her in-house tailoring business to a very competitive market arena. Janet decided to join Yehu so as get a loan to start a business. She rents a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food.

loans.use: To buy cloth, sewing thread, and a sewing machine

loans.name: Ameto

texts.en:
Ameto N. is currently in the business of selling mosquito nets and bedsheets at the market and is requesting a loan to stock pairs of shoes and sandals to sell.  Ameto is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build another shop and buy sewing machines. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock pairs of shoes and sandals to sell

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en: Leonila T. is from the town of Villa Marzo Cordon. She is 59 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Leonila owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transportation. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month. In 2005, Leonila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be her tenth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Lok

texts.en: Mrs. Lok L., 30, has a life partner in her husband who appears on the right of the photo, and they live in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. Lok L. currently earns her daily revenue by selling fresh fish and some meats to villagers in front of her home. Her husband is a construction foreman. The couple has one young child who is of school age. Because fish-selling is the main source of family income, Lok L. is applying for a Kiva loan to sustain its growth.

loans.use: To sustain fish-selling business

loans.name: Anwer's Group

texts.en:
Anwer bibi has applied for a loan to financially support her husband who wants to expand his business of selling goats. 
He buys goats, raises them, and then sells them for a profit. He will buy more goats from the loan money. 

Anwer bibi also does embroidery work to support her family financially. She has two sons and both of them work independently. She is hopeful that investment in her husband’s business will bring their financial problems to an end. She is hopeful for a better future.

loans.use: Purchase goats to sell

loans.name: Akuru

texts.en:
Akuru M. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Akuru is 31 years old and is married with a husband that is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Suy

texts.en: Mr. Suy S., 24, is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has another partner in his wife, who appears in the picture above. She farms rice and vegetable crops to earn a living. The couple has a young child who is not enrolled in school. Suy S. currently lives in an older house that needs repairs. Because he has no money, he is requesting a loan in order to mend his old house.

loans.use: To mend his old house.

loans.name: Melvin

texts.en: Melvin V. is from the town of Villa Marzo Cordon. He is 27 years old and is married. Melvin owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Aside from his general store, he also ventures in the printing of T-shirt designs as his other source of income. In 2009, Melvin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Melvin is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his second from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Evalina

texts.en:
Evalina L. is currently in the business of selling maize and sorghum at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell.  Evalina is 31 years old and is married with a husband that is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a store for her goods.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
This village loan, which consists of twenty-one people, is located in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mai S. is 39 years old and is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Mai S. is a seamstress in a garment factory where she earns a small salary to support her family. In order to increase her income to improve her family’s living conditions, she is now requesting a loan to buy vegetables to resell. With her new business, she hopes her family living conditions will improve and be better than before.

Mrs. Mai S. is a widow with two children: one is a farm laborer while the youngest one is 5 years old.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Luningning

texts.en:
Luningning T. is an optimistic businesswoman who knows that she will overcome all challenges and achieve her dreams. As a busy woman, Luningning is a determined entrepreneur.  With this loan, Luningning will purchase additional fish to sell and other raw materials of her fishing business.  

A model member of ASHI, Luningning has achieved strong performance with regular attendance at group meetings and timely loan repayments.  As a hard working businesswoman, she is thankful for the opportunity to earn income independently. Her long-term goals are to have a successful fish farm business, to fund the college education of her 5 children, and support her family economically.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial venture.

loans.use: Purchase of additional fish to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca M is currently in the business of selling maize flour and fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell.  Rebecca is 51 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Kashi

texts.en: Kashi A. C. is a married woman with four children who do not attend school because she cannot afford to pay pay their school fees. Her husband is old and can’t help her in raising their children. Kashi has been selling food, mainly dumplings made of flour, in an open air market just outside her house for the past ten years. This  business is her only source of income. Her major business challenge includes seasonality as she says that she cannot sell at the open air market during rainy seasons. She hopes one day that her business will grow and support her family comfortably.  She owns a home with electricity but no piped water. Her major expenses are high food costs.She is requesting a  KShs 40,000 loan to buy wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.use: Toy  buy a sack of wheat flour, 20 litres of cooking oil and 50kgs of sugar

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en: Annabelle D. is from Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Annabelle owns and operates a butcher shop, butchering and selling pork in the market. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Annabelle joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annabelle is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Sareth's Group

texts.en:
Twenty-four members make up this village bank loan, located in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sareth T., 46 years old, is the village bank president who has beE. selected by the members. Each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Sareth T. and her husband, Mr. Soeun Sao, are farmers who rent some land to grow crops. For this farm, Mrs. Sareth T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump to support her crops.

This couple has six childrE.: one is a laborer, one is a worker in a small company, while the other four are attending the local school and also support their parents’ farming.

loans.use: To buy a water pump to irrigate her crops

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen M. A. lives in Vehari, a small city in the  Punjab, Pakistan. She has four children and they are getting their education.
Yasmeen has applied for a loan for her business of sewing clothes, With the loan she will buy a new electric sewing machine. This will help her to improve her sewing because her current sewing machine needs replacement. Yasmeen started this business to financially support her husband whose income is not enough to meet the basic needs of the family. Yasmeen works very hard because she wants to provide her children with the best education possible.

loans.use: To purchase an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Mrs. Ban S. is 28 years of age, married to Mr. Chin, age 40, and they have no any children. To make a living, this couple leaves home early in order to buy fruit from the places where it is sold in bulk and bring it to sell retail inside the local market. By doing this, they are able to generate around $9 each day to meet the family’s daily expenses. Ban S. estimates that her current income will be not enough to serve them when their child is born. She hopes to invest in a new business line so she can earn extra income. Because she doesn’t have capital, Ban S. has applied for a loan for the capital to  begin a business raising pigs.

loans.use: To begin a business raising pigs.

loans.name: Munguntsetseg

texts.en:
Munguntsetseg  C. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Darkhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own apartment. Their  daughter is 19 years old and a university student. 
Munguntsetseg operates a beauty products trading business. Once a month, Munguntsetseg gets new products from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her product selection is very good and she has a great business mind. But she wants to increase current assets and purchase more products from Beijing, a Chinese border city. Because of the  high-quality products she receives from Beijing, the products she offers are usually better than those offered by other sellers. Since Munguntsetseg started her business, her family's living conditions have improved. With her earnings, she has been providing money for family expenses and paying her daughter's education fees. Munguntsetseg  is an open and very hardworking person.  She is requesting a loan to purchase additional beauty products.

loans.use: To purchase additional beauty products to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth P. is from Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 56 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Ruth owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Ruth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en: G. Fatima lives in the  small city of Vehari which is located in Pakistan. She is the  mother of two sons, Both of them work. They couldn’t complete their education for  financial reasons. G. Fatima sells clothes. She buys them in  big cities like Lahore and sells them to different shops in the market. G. Fatima's husband has a grocery shop in the market. G. Fatima has applied for a loan to increase the stock of grocery items in her husband's shop.

loans.use: To purchase items for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Saidahon's Group

texts.en:
In daily life, people engaged in business do not usually have time and eagerness to discuss current issues and talk politics as they have a general idea that politics and decisions of political leaders have only a small impact on their individual lives. Twenty years ago, when the collapse of Soviet Union took place, people living in the republics within did not even realize the far reaching consequences of this event. One of those consequences was the halt of almost all major industrial factories, which led to the increase in unemployment and deterioration of economic conditions. Consequently people began to leave their homelands in mass for foreign lands in search of jobs and ways of earning a wage. Saidahon T. is the leader of this group. She is thirty two years old. Her husband is working in the  Russian Federation. Every now and then he sends money to his family, which consists of five members: himself , Saidahon and their three children. Their eldest daughter is ten. She has already started helping her mother doing some light work around the house.  Saidahon prefers not to depend on her husband’s support for a living and is engaged in cattle breeding. She also has a cow and sells milk. Saidahon hopes to obtain this loan to purchase wood for building. 
Saidahon’s partners: 

Diloramhon M., 39, has three children. She trades in foodstuffs. Her husband is a car maintainer. Diloramhon manages to earn 200$ a month. Now she needs this loan to purchase soft drinks and ice - cream. During the summer, this is very profitable trade. 

Etiborhan O., 59, is a widow. She has two children, who live separately. Etiborhan used to work in a hospital, but left because of the  low salary  and started to raise cattle. Now she has two sheep and a cow. Etiborhan hopes to obtain this loan and purchase two calves.

Kuranbaeva N., 31, is a mother of two children. She and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. Now they have four sheep and a cow. N. decided to apply for this loan as they need funds for building their new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase wood for building

loans.name: Enhtuul

texts.en: Enhtuul Y. is 38 years old and lives in a small house in the Narantuul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She is divorced from her husband and lives with her only daughter and younger sister who are both students. Enhtuul operates a tailoring business out of her home. She has been working on her own since 2000 after gaining experience working in her sister's clothing factory for several years. She makes tailored clothes according to her customers' requests in addition to the original items she produces for sale at the nearby Narantuul market. She has made much progress with her business over the years and has used her earnings to purchase a new sewing machine. In the future, she plans to enlarge her business by expanding the variety and styles of clothes she produces. She hopes to move her business from her home to a permanent work location. She says, “ I hope to move my parents from the countryside so they can live with us in the city.” Enhtuul is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to add another room onto her house as well as build a garage.

loans.use: To add another room onto her house as well as build a garage

loans.name: Miraflor

texts.en: Miraflor C. is from Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old, is married, and has three infant children. Miraflor owns and operates a business making and selling food, preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Miraflor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en: Franklin C. is from the village of Barangay Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 41 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Franklin owns and operates a business operating motorcycle transport services. Franklin has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Franklin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Franklin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Franklin is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a new engine. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Franklin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a new engine

loans.name: Phim's Group

texts.en: Almost every dawn and late afternoon, Phim M. rushes to the riverside to gather the fish from her husband on his small fishing boat and hurries to the market. She sells at retail so that she will get a  suitable price. Phim M. is 30 years old has given birth to four children all of whom are still young and attend school. Recently, some fishing tools the family uses have broken  down and this has been affecting their income. Phim M. will use this loan to repair the broken tools as well as buy more to fish. She is the leader of the  four member group. Mrs. N. and Mrs. T. spend their  life on the water also, while Mrs. K. sells porridge to earn a living,  All of these women will use their  loans to sustain their business growth.

loans.use: To repair  broken tools as well as buy new to fish.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en: Shamim W. M. lives in Vehari with her husband and a fifteen year old son who couldn’t get an education due to the financial condition of the family. Shamim’s husband is a government employee with a very little income. It has not been easy for him to fulfill the financial needs of the family. Shamim bibi decided to support her husband and started a clothes selling business by taking a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva). She purchases beautiful embroidered clothes in Multan, a city in the Punjab region of Pakistan which is famous for embroidered works, and sells them at different local shops and to her neighbors as well. Now she has applied for another loan from Asasah. With the help of a loan, Shamim will buy clothes in bulk which will minimize the cost of traveling and also enable her to fulfill larger orders from her customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
48 year-old Elvira N. is happy with the life she has. She never regretted her decision not to get married and to spend most of her time instead looking after the needs of her parents as well as her nieces. At home, she lives with her 71 year-old father and 72 year- old mother. Her two nieces, ages five and 12, are the great source of joy in their house. Elvira’s sister (mother of her nieces) is a housewife and is dependent on her husband’s small income as a hired laborer. Aside from supporting the needs of her parents, Elvira also wanted to help  support her sister and her nieces. 
A way Elvira realized to have a source of income to support her dream of improving her family’s standard of living is by having her own business. With that vision, she joined ASHI in 2004 and has put up a small variety store which sells groceries, foodstuffs and beverages. Eventually, as the amount of loan she is qualified to request from ASHI increased because of maintaining an excellent credit rating (business rating, attendance to center meetings, and repayment rating) inventories of her store increased as well as her profit. Looking back on their lives before she had her own business, now it’s quite different, and financially life has improved. 
With the loan Elvira  is currently requesting, she hopes to enhance her other business which is hog fattening. After four months of fattening her hogs, they will be sold either alive or slaughtered directly to people in their village and/or in the market. Proceeds from this business would augment the proceeds of her store and therefore, Elvira will be able to raise her family out of poverty.

loans.use: Some portion will be used to purchase a larger volume of grocery items for her store and some will be used to purchase piglets for starting a hog fattening business.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: S. is 30 years old and a resident of the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She makes a living raising pigs, which she sells for slaughter four months after raising them. She has been raising pigs for about four years. S. is married with three children, all of whom attend school. She has a life partner in her husband who works in the construction field. This is the second cycle of the loan she has requested. S. is taking out her loan to purchase a piglet for her pig pen.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia R. is from the coastal town of Talim, Binangonan, Rizal. She is 52 and married and with three children. Ofelia sells fish in her village and nearby town. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a week. In 2008, Ofelia joined ASHI to secure access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.Ofelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASHI which was used to purchase fishing equipment. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fishnets and bamboos. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Ofelia from ASHI. She plans to use the additional proceeds to develop her business. She hopes that, with the help of ASHI and KIVA, she can reach her ambition to move out from poverty, expand her fishing business, and pay for the education of her youngest daughter.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishnets and bamboos.

loans.name: Sor Dolores

texts.en:
Sor Dolores M. is from the village of District 4. She is 36 years old and single. To make a living, Sor Dolores owns and operates a business that provides photocopying services. She has been engaged in her business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month. To provide additional income, she also manages a general store.

In 2006, Sor Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. That loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Sor Dolores is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Sor Dolores from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Madinahon's Group

texts.en:
Madinahon T. is the leader of this group. She is twenty seven and has a one–year-old son. To provide for the family her husband works as a taxi driver. He earns 43 to 45$ a month. Madinahon has a small farm with ten cows, five calves and thirty sheep. She also works at the local school as a math teacher. Madinahon has been familiar with cattle breeding since her childhood and, after getting married, this skill greatly helped her family with extra funds. Madinahon’s monthly income is around $110. During the past few years, she has managed to increase her livestock, make repairs to her house, and buy a car. With this loan Madinahon plans to purchase cattle forage and a cell phone. 

Madinahon’s partners: 

O. Zulfiya, 34, has three children. Her husband is disabled and has a pension. To provide for the family, Zulfiya grows cotton and does odd jobs, which brings her $2.50 per day. Zulfiya has applied for this loan to purchase mineral and nitric fertilizers.

Marhabo T., 32, is a mother of three children. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Marhabo breeds cattle and spends fall and spring in pastures looking after them. She also sells milk products. Now, Marhabo needs a loan to purchase two cows. 

Mavludahon M., 29, has three children. Her husband is among those who have left the country in search of work. He is now working in Russia as a builder. Mavludahon does odd jobs and also has an allowance. She needs this loan for repair works in the house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle forage and a cell phone

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en: Oyun T., age 32, lives with her husband, daughter and father in the Narantuul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. They have lived there for the past 5 years. Her husband has been employed as a polishing worker in at a geology lab for five years and her daughter is in middle school. Since 2007, Oyun has run a clothes trading business at the nearby Narantuul market, the largest market in the city. She rents a stall which she considers to be in a good location because of its close proximity to the food market. Over the past two years Oyun has made a lot of progress with her business. Currently her daily revenues average around 50,000 MNT and sometimes reach 150,000 on a good day. Oyun is a very easy going, hardworking and responsible woman. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase and import clothes from China to sell at her stall.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Razia Begum's Group

texts.en: Razia begum lives in a small city of Vehari Pakistan. A few years ago her husband died which was very difficult for her and her family but she never gave up hope. She started selling clothes, taking orders from the big shops and the families of her community and filling them with purchases made in Faisalabad (famous for its textile industry). Her only son works in a school. He had to leave his education after the death of his father. Razia begum has applied for a loan from Asasah because she wants to buy clothes in bulk for which she needs capital. With this she will be able to take larger orders and increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Purevjargal

texts.en:
Purevjargal C., age 56, lives with his wife and two sons in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. They live together in a small house which they own. His wife is currently unemployed and his sons are both grown and working.

Purevjargal currently operates a small transportation business in his local area. His oldest son recently returned from work in South Korea and works as a taxi driver along with his father. He says, “Our family is very close and we have been working in the transportation field for the past twenty-five years.”

Purevjargal is hardworking and is trusted by his many customers as a very experienced driver. He is very optimistic about the future and hopes to one day expand his business by opening a sawmill. He is modest, creative and very keen on expanding his business to improve his quality of life. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wood and timber to sell.

loans.use: To purchase wood and timber to sell

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag B. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Mongolia's capital city, Ulaanbaatar. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian tent home called a ger. Her daughter is currently training in the Mongolian Police Academy and her son is in middle school.

Tugalag has operated a leather handicrafts business since moving to Ulaanbaatar with her family in 2006, having previously worked as a storekeeper in her former town. She learned from her parents how to make handicraft items and specializes in leather processing. She processes each cow skin into one noose, four fetlock leathers, forty girth straps, and one bridle. Her business is quite successful as she makes revenues of around 111,000 MNT from one skin. She sells her products at Intolerant market, the largest market in the city.

Tungalag is a very hardworking woman and manual leather processing is very strenuous and intensive work. The work has begun to take its toll on her arms after only four years of operation. She hopes to continue her success into the future and says, “We are trying to have our own home." She is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase more cowhides as demand is beginning to increase for the busy summer season.

loans.use: To purchase more cowhides

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg N., age 44, lives with her husband and four children in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent, called a ger, on a small plot of land which they own. Her two daughters are both university students and her youngest son is in middle school. Her oldest son is currently unemployed and helps his parents with the family business.

Since 2005, after moving from the countryside, Oyunchimeg and her husband, who work well together, have been operating a clothing and shoe repair business out of a rented room. She makes and sells a variety of clothing items and her husband repairs shoes.

Oyunchimeg has many plans to expand her business in the future. She plans to purchase another three sewing machines in order to make her business more efficient and keep up with the growing demand.

Oyunchimeg is an open minded and generous woman. “We are trying our best to make more profit by working overtime so we can grow our business,” she says with a smile. She is requesting a 1,400,000 MNT loan to purchase three new sewing machines.

loans.use: To purchase three new sewing machines

loans.name: Anees' Group

texts.en:
Anees bibi lives in the mid-sized city of Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband works in the government sector with a very small pay. She has a son who couldn’t complete his education due to financial reasons and had to start work to support his family financially.

Anees bibi is a housewife but she also works, selling milk. Her business is doing well but most of the time she faces a problem completing her orders due to the fact that she has only one buffalo, which sometimes gives a good amount of milk and sometimes not.

Anees bibi wants to increase her income and for that purpose she has applied for this loan. She will buy another buffalo with the loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase another buffalo for her milk-selling business

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en:
Oyuntsetseg R., age 47, lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. For the past twenty years they have lived together in a ger (the traditional Mongolian tent home) on a small plot of land they own. Her husband currently operates a transport service using his truck and they have two grown daughters who live on their own.

Oyuntsetseg operates a meat-trading business at Narantuul market, the largest market in the city. She has operated this business for the last ten years and has become quite a successful businesswoman. She purchases meat at a wholesale price from Huchit Shonhor, a meat supply market. In the summer, she purchases almost daily because supplies are plentiful. However, in the winter, she must buy a large amount to set aside in storage. Her main meat product is high-quality horse meat.

Oyuntsetseg is an open-minded, generous and hardworking woman. She says, “Life is beautiful. My two daughters are married and I am full of happiness.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to support her youngest daughter who will soon travel to Japan for foreign study.

loans.use: To support her youngest daughter who will soon travel to Japan for foreign study

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome K. M. is thirty-one years old. She is married and they have three children. Her husband is a driver and they see themselves opening a big hotel (restaurant) in Mariakani, Mombasa, where her current business is located. Mariakani is a very busy market with many customers.

Salome has been supplying tomatoes at the market for the last six years. She says that the business is good and that the only major challenge is the seasonal changes which make tomatoes very expensive. She is taking a loan of Kes 40,000 to add to her stock of tomatoes to grow her business.

Salome describes herself as God-fearing and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Tsanjidmaa

texts.en:
Tsanjidmaa B. is 51 years old and lives with her family in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. Her family enjoys a comfortable lifestyle and they all are in good health. Her husband and oldest son both work as drivers and her youngest son is an electrician for a construction company.

Tsanjidmaa operates a wood and timber trading business in her area. Since starting in 2006 she has made much progress with her business and has used her business to improve her family's life. She is optimistic about the future and hopes to work with her husband to expand his transportation business to an adjoining province.

Tsanjidmaa is a modest woman and always remains optimistic about achieving her goals. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase timber for her business and petrol (gasoline) for her transport truck.

loans.use: To purchase more timber to sell and gasoline for her truck

loans.name: Dorlig

texts.en:
Dorlig is 46 years old and lives with his wife and four sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in a small house. His older sons, Unenbat and Tsagaantsooj, attend university while his two younger sons, Chimiddorj and Turbold, attend a secondary school.

Dorlig operates a taxi service in the city and enjoys transporting people. He also works in a high school as an engineer. Generally he operates his taxi business with his older son, Unenbat: they drive the taxi in the early morning and at night.

Dorlig is very hardworking and is known for his good character. He has gained a lot of experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. He works hard to maintain his success and is hopeful about the future. He is requesting a loan to fix his house’s heating system.

loans.use: To fix his house’s heating system

loans.name: Amaan Mai's Group

texts.en:
Amaan Mai is a resident of a small city in Pakistan called Vehari where she lives in a brick house with her husband and four children. Her family’s financial condition was not good and that’s why her older son had to leave his studies and start work. This helped his younger sisters to continue their education.

Amaan Mai’s husband owns a grocery store and Amaan Mai works with him there. The two of them work in shifts: Amaan Mai does her duty in the morning and her husband works the rest of the day. In this way both work very hard to earn a living for their family.

Amaan Mai and her husband want to expand their business by adding more grocery items to their shop. This will help them increase their sales and their income.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her grocery store

loans.name: Sicilia

texts.en:
Sicilia U. O. is forty-five years old. She is married to a businessman and they have four children.

Sicilia’s business is located at Kongowea market in Mombasa town. Kongowea is a very busy market situated by the roadside. She sells tea leaves to the local people and she has been in this business for the last ten years.

Sicilia says the business is very good except during the rainy season because it is an open air market. In future, she hopes to buy a plot and build a business premises. She describes herself as honest, determined, self-motivated and God fearing.

loans.use: To buy more tea leaves to sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma S. has successfully paid her first Kiva loan! With the loan, she purchased more piglets, grew them and already sold them in the market. She is so thankful for your support and the opportunity to borrow money from Kiva. Norma is very happy that she was able to buy and sell the animals without delay because of the loan. She wishes to access a larger loan to expand her hog-raising business of buying and selling of pigs so she can earn more profit. Norma thanks Kiva for providing her with opportunity to increase her income. Your support is important to her family and they are very grateful. Norma’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of shortage. Over the years, she has provided for her family by other work involving hog raising, including slaughtering and tending to farming business in her village. Now she is proposing another Kiva loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos for hog fattening, a common business for people in her area suffering from poverty. Norma will buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale. With the support of ASHI, a Kiva partner, she is hopeful that her hog-fattening business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and supplements and vitamins for the piglets

loans.name: Syedaan's Group

texts.en:
Syedaan lives in the mid-sized city of Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband is a loader; he loads items on a donkey cart and delivers them to the required places. She has three children: two sons and one daughter. She couldn’t educate her children due to financial constraints. 

She has a business of animal selling. She purchases animals from the animal market, grows them up, then sells them to earn a profit. Recently, she started embroidery work to earn money for buying animals.
 
She is saving money from her earnings through embroidery, but she has still a shortage of money needed to buy animals. She is applying for the loan to cover that cost. 

She is hopeful that with the help of the profits, one day she will be able to send her younger children to school.

loans.use: Purchase animals for selling

loans.name: Balikyejjusa Development Group, Mityana

texts.en: 42 year old M. Mohamad, a married man with 7 children and 9 dependants operates a salon business in Namutidde, Mityana. This family recourse business has been in existence for 6 years.  What M. has always been bearing in mind during the course of operating his business has been that unavoidable requisite business ethic-being cordial to his customers. This method of operation has bore a resonance with his clients and explains why his business is growing. His future goal is to build his own small rental apartments where he envisions eking out more profits to supplement on what he gets from his main business. He also wants to be in a better financial position to give his children and dependants a better education. His business has been drawing in 60,000 shillings a week. With this loan, he is upbeat at the prospect of being able to inject more capital into his business with the sole and set objective of giving it a firm short and long term success foundation.

loans.use: To purchase hairdryers, cosmetics, weavers, etc.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris K. S. is 42 years old. She is married and has four children. Her business is located at Mariakani, a very busy market in Mombasa, and it is known by the name "Dama's Cereals." 

She sells maize, beans and peas to the local people.She says the business is very profitable and she would like to grow it more. She says that she really loves what she does and she plans to build a premise where she can run her business better. 

She is using her loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to restock her business. She is hardworking and God-fearing.

loans.use: Maize, beans, peas

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina lives in Vehari, Pakistan, with her husband and two children. Her elder son is in a 4th class but her daughter is too young to attend school yet. 
Her husband is a daily-wage laborer and also does the business of animal selling. He thinks that there is potential in this business; that’s why he wants to expand it. 

Zarina is also a very caring lady. She takes care of her family and manages the household chores. She also takes care of the animals. Presently, they have a buffalo at their house.  

Zarina bibi has applied for a loan for her husband. He can buy more animals and improve the financial conditions of their family.

loans.use: Purchase animlas to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and six siblings. He and all of his siblings work to help support the family expenses. He has owned a shop to sell different types of household goods since 1995. These kinds of stores are popular throughout Lebanon and require salesmen to be constantly aware of customers’ needs. He works hard to satisfy the heavy demands of the life in Lebanon as all the Lebanese people.

He is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. He plans to use the loan to increase his store’s inventory and bring new items to his shop to attract more clients and make a good profit. This will be his first loan from Ameen and he's certain that it will allow him to develop his business.

loans.use: To increase his store’s inventory

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane C. I. is 47 years of age, single and has one son who is 24 years old. Her business is located at Mariakani, a busy market in Mombasa. She makes and sells clothes to the local people. She has been in this business for 10 years now. 

She says that the business is good, although at times, prices for materials escalate, making it hard for the local people to purchase from her frequently. She is using her loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more materials and clothes to resell. She hopes to grow her business in the future and build a home. She describes herself as social and friendly.

loans.use: Clothes, materials

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with two children who still attend school. He has been working in the jewelry business for the past 36 years. He and his brother own their own shop where they make jewelry. He also makes customized pieces of jewelry on the side. This man is requesting a $1,000 loan from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase new inventory and tools for his work.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory and tools for his work

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame Coumba F. est membre à la caisse de liberté 6 depuis le mois d'Aout 2009 elle habite non loin de la caisse la cinquantaine elle  sollicite un deuxième crédit d'un montant de 400 000 F CFA pour acheter une machine a coudre, des tissus et de la teinture (thioup) pour  attirer la clientèle et mieux vendre ses produits
texts.en:
Mrs. Coumba F. has been a member of the Liberté 6 bank since August 2009. She does not live far form the bank. She is in her fifties and is requesting a second loan in the amount of 400 000 Francs CFA to buy fabric and dyes in order to attract customers and to better sell her products.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabric and dyes.

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia lives in a small city of Punjab Pakistan called Vehari, where she is a very good housewife and a great mother of two children. She shares the financial support of her family with her husband by sewing clothes, receiving orders from her neighbors and relatives. Her reasonable charges ensure repeat business. Her husband has been selling farm supplies for five years, retailing seeds and fertilizer to farmers and land owners.

Safia is now requesting her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) to help her husband in his work.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and seeds to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 28-year old man living in Lebanon. He lives with father and brother, who both work to help each other with the home expenses. He has worked as a barber for the past 10 years, but after working in this industry for 4 years he decided to open up his own barber shop. He is requesting a $1,200 loan from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to improve the shop.

loans.use: to improve the shop

loans.name: Agalyawamu Busimbi Members Group, Mityana

texts.en:
N. Jane is 52 years old and has been contentedly married for a reasonably long period of time. She has seven children with her husband who she refers to endearingly as her “light in shining amour”. All their children are in the later stages of their education due to Jane’s down-the-line unwavering hardwork ethic she has brought forth in her produce-selling business in Wabigalo, Mityana for the last fifteen years.

At length, Jane’s good customer-care skills have lent her that countenance in establishing a lasting relationship with most of her clientele. She reckons a bright future beckons on the horizon for her business as she will be able to significantly expand her business with the support of this loan. She also wants to give all her children a quality education.

With this loan, Jane wants to purchase more quantities of produce like maize, beans, cassava, yams and cabbages.

loans.use: To purchase more produce to sell

loans.name: Rukhsana Kousar's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana Kousar lives with her husband and one son in a two room brick house in Vehari, Pakistan. Her husband has been involved in the business of selling goats for the last 5 years. Rukhsana operates a domestic sewing business. She receives orders from her neighbors and gets reasonable compensation from them.

Rukhsana has applied for a loan for her husband, who wants to buy more goats for the expansion of his business. She is hopeful that by making an investment in his business, he will be able to make more money. This will help her to send her son to school, as he is not presently enrolled in a school due to financial constraints.

loans.use: to purchases goats for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 32-year old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and three small children. She has owned her own women's clothing and lingerie store for the past ten years, to help her husband with the family expenses. She is requesting $1,000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Thekheye

texts.fr: Thekheye F. est un jeune mécanicien  marié père de famille il est membre a la caisse de liberté depuis 2009 il sollicite un crédit d'un montant de 500 000 F CFA pour acheter / réparer des véhicules et les revendre pour augmenter son pouvoir d'achat et mieux subvenir aux besoin familiaux
texts.en:
Thekheye F. is a young mechanic, married and a father. He has been a member of the Liberté bank branch since 2009. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 500 000 Francs CFA to buy and repair vehicles and to resell them. This would increase his buying power and allow him to better meet his family’s needs.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vehicles to fix and resale.

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.fr: Ndèye N. est une femme de 49 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants et tutrice de 6 autres qui lui sont confiés par des proches et parents. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de CENTRE2 depuis le 08 janvier 2004 et a reçu 2 fois de suite de crédit. Elle fait un commerce de tissus teintés et de chaussures et son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'intensifier son activité en achetant beaucoup plus de marchandise et d'augmenter sa clientèle. Les bénéfices qu'elle réalise sont utilisés pour l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille et payer la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Ndèye N. is 49 years old, married and the mother of three children. She is also the tutor of six other children entrusted to her by relations and family. She has been a member of the CENTRE2 “Banc Villageois” loan group since 8 January 2004 and has been granted two successive loans. Her business activity is the retail sales of dyed fabrics and shoes. Her new loan will enable her to intensify her activity by purchasing much more merchandise, and increase the number of customers. Her earnings will be used to improve the family’s living conditions and pay the children’s tuition fees.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her activity retailing dyed fabrics and shoes

loans.name: Ayawo

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur a ouvert depuis 2007 sa propre boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale, son stock actuel ne lui permet pas de satisfaire tous ses clients, il doit se réapprovisionner, c’est pour cette raison qu’il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 10 sacs de riz, 4 sacs de sucres, 8 cartons de tomates, 5 cartons de vin  et divers.
Il est père de famille et ce commerce lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman opened his own general food store in 2007. His current stock levels do not enable him to satisfy all his customers, which is why he needs to resupply and is requesting from Wages a loan to buy 10 bags of rice, 4 bags of sugar, 8 crates of tomatoes, 5 cartons of wine and various other items. He is a father and the business enables him to meet his family’s needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy general food products

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 19-year old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and sibling. His father started teaching him about the jewelry business 10 years ago, which made him ambitious about the industry and pushed him to work on his own. He then opened his own jewelry store.

Today he is requesting a $1,000 loan from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new machine in order to improve his productivity.

loans.use: to purchase a new machine.

loans.name: Matar

texts.fr: Matar S. est un jeune homme marié père de 2 enfants il habite non loin de la caisse de liberté 6 et détient un laboratoire photo il sollicite un prêt à la caisse d'un montant de 300 000 F CFA pour acheter du papier à photo, des pellicules, renforcer ses activités de tirage photo et filmer des cérémonies de mariage ce qui lui permettra de mieux gagner et acheter un terrain à dakar
texts.en:
Matar S. is a young married father of two children. He lives not far from the « Caisse de Liberté 6 » branch office. As he owns a photographer’s shop he requested a loan for 300,000 FCFA from the branch to buy photo paper and film. This will enable him to expand his photo printing activity and take on wedding ceremonies. His earnings will increase and he will be able to buy a plot of land in Dakar.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy photo paper and film, among other items

loans.name: Akou Delali

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce dans la restauration, sa spécialité est la cuisine togolaise, elle est très réputée dans son entourage car elle fait de la bonne cuisine.
