She will also use some of the loan to do advance orders on her direct selling line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also wishes that she can have enough profits from the business to renovate her house.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen T., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Perigryn T., a driver, and they are blessed with six children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own piggery while overseeing their slipper-making business. She also owns a clothing store and a hot dog / hamburger stand.

Carmen has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Carmen would like to apply for an 18,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy more products for her clothing and snack stand. She will also invest some of the loan into buying feed for her swine and raw materials for their slipper business. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To bug more products for a clothing and snack stand and for hog feed and raw materials for a slipper business

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena A., 34, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Joey A., and they are blessed with a child in their marriage. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store and selling toys and snack items.

Lorena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Lorena would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy more products for her inventory. Lorena dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Cencia

texts.en:
Along with her supportive husband and six loving children, 44-year-old Cencia R. hails from one of the most depressed areas of the municipality of Pandan, in Antique Province. The area lacks access to markets, hospitals, and a good standard of education due to very poor road conditions and very few vehicles for transportation, and because of this Cencia and her family are not able to the enjoy standard of living others do. Cencia was not able to send her three eldest children to college and has not been able to make her business stable. Her husband is just a hired driver who earns a small amount of money every day. The income generated by her business is a great opportunity to augment her husband’s income, yet it has not been enough to supply all the things her children need, especially for their education. In spite of that, Cencia and her husband have never stopped dreaming and hoping to improve their standard of living. They keep on inspiring and motivating their children to hold on to life and face the challenges it throws at them.

In 2003, Cencia got to know about ASHI and realized the opportunity it brings for the achievement of her dreams. She has been able to put up a small variety store through the loans she has gotten. This business has improved their standard of living. It also helps people in their village get access to the most common needs for their everyday life. Cencia is requesting a much larger loan through ASHI to grow her business further until it becomes sustainable. The proceeds of her business will be used to support the education of her other three children who will go to school until they graduate from college and have a better life in the future.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, foodstuff, and beverages for her variety store's inventory.

loans.name: Febe

texts.en:
Febe P., 40, is making sure that her family has enough to provide for their daily needs. She is a single mother with two children. She makes sure that she earns well so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own food stall business while also selling ready-to-wear items and silver jewelry for quite some time now.

Febe has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 50,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more ready-to-wear items, silver jewelry and raw ingredients needed to continue production of her food stall business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also dreams of being able to put up her own commercial space.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients for her food stall business, some ready-to-wear items and various designs of silver jewelry.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Thirty-four-year-old Janeth E. dreams of her two children (10 and 12 years old) graduating from college. For her, good quality and a higher level of education is the only wealth she can leave to her children once her life is over. This could not be stolen away from them by anyone and would lead them towards a brighter future. Their diploma from college would give them employment that will provide them with a stable and sound compensation to support their needs. With this dream, Janeth and her husband work hard to earn money.

Janeth joined ASHI in 2008 and has received several loans since then. With those loans, she has been able to have a source of financial capital to support the growth of her husband’s fishing business as well as providing herself with the livelihood activity of fish selling. The proceeds they get out of their business go to the needs of her children and the entire family. Since then, their life has eventually changed a little. With the loan she is requesting now, Janeth is optimistic that someday she will finally bring her family out of poverty by making her business stable and profitable.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing gear to improve the quality of her husband's fishing business.

loans.name: Has

texts.en: Mrs. Has P. is 45 years of age, a widow and the mother of four teenagers who are no longer in school. All four of her children are now employed in different occupations for the purpose of helping to manage the financial crisis of the family. In order to earn a daily income, Has P. owns a cart that she uses to sell roasted meatballs around her community. By doing this, she is able to generate around $3 each day. Presently, Has P. can attract a lot of clients to eat the meatballs as their snacks because she is skilled in public relations. To earn more income and to make her business more successful, Has P. is looking for a loan as the extra capital for her meatball-selling business.

loans.use: To use as extra capital for her business selling meatballs.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Mrs. Him S. is a Cambodian laborer who has been working in the local garment industry, located in the middle of Phnom Penh, for more than eight years. Her husband helps her support their family by fishing in Tunle Sap Lake. She is 40 years old and has given birth to four children. Two of the children are now married and sell fish, for their occupation. The other two children attend school or go to work. This is the second cycle of loan that she has requested. Him S. will use this loan to add to her savings in order to purchase a motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Ниёзмадов Нурулло проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 43 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, работает в районной больнице медсестрой. Сам Нурулло имеет высшее образование. Был военнослужащим. Сейчас он занимается торговлей. У него продуктовый магазин. Этим видом бизнеса занимается 2 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Нурулло хочет расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Nurullo N. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 43 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife works as a nurse in the regional hospital. Nurullo himself has a higher education and has served in the army. Now he works in retail - he owns a grocery store. He has been engaged in this type of business for two years. He is applying for credit to increase sales volume. Nurullo would like to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase business turnover

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn R., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Jocelyn, a widow with two children, has always been challenged to provide daily needs for her family. She makes sure that she earns well so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own general store for years and is now planning to expand to a new variety store.

Jocelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP50,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of groceries, beverages and other items for the opening of her new variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide an education for her children. She also dreams to be able to buy their own house and lot. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying additional items for her existing general store and to buy bulk groceries and softdrinks for a new expansion.

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.ru: Мусоев Чамшед проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 32 года. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Брат, преподает в средней школе. Сам Чамшед имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. У него магазин, где он продает мужскую одежду и обувь. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Jamshed M. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 32 years old, married, with 7 children. His wife is a housewife. His brother is a middle school teacher. Jamshed himself has a secondary education. He has worked in retail for more than five years. He owns a store where he sells men's clothing and shoes. He is applying for credit to increase the selection of merchandise at his store.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase merchandise selection

loans.name: Jeaneth

texts.en:
Jeaneth J. is from the village of Nacional, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 22 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Jeaneth owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as biscuits (cookies), shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2008, Jeaneth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jeaneth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Richell

texts.en:
Richell C. is from the village of Poblacion 3, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old and is married. Richell owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transportation services. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Richell joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 60,000 PHP from GDMPC. Richell is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be her eighth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle

loans.name: Mercell

texts.en:
At the age of 28, Mercell G. has proven her ability to manage a business and becomes productive. This was noticed by the staff of ASHI handling the ASHI center she belongs to since she became a member in 2007. Now she is qualified to request a much larger loan to really grow her business until it becomes stable and profitable.

Mercell wouldn’t want to let this opportunity pass her by. She really wants to grow her small hog-raising business into a piggery which means she can raise a large volume of hogs and sell them either live or slaughtered in the market and/or directly to the people in their village. 

Being a single parent to her only child, who is five years old now, she has to have a stable source of income to support his needs and education until he graduates from college. As a mother, she would not have anything else in this world to dream about but for her child to have a life out from under the umbrella of poverty. This is where the proceeds of her business will go.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and fatten and pig feed

loans.name: Meme

texts.en:
Meme T. is from the village of Kinangay Sur, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Meme owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transport services. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Meme joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Meme is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle to provide better service
